						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">Birthday problem</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-navigation">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Lead_too_short&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Lead too short (page does not exist)">Template:Lead too short</a>
In <a href="/wiki/Probability_theory" title="Probability theory">probability theory</a>, the <b>birthday problem</b> or <b>birthday <a href="/wiki/Paradox" title="Paradox">paradox</a></b><sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup> concerns the <a href="/wiki/Probability" title="Probability">probability</a> that, in a set of <i>n</i> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Random&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Random (page does not exist)">randomly</a> chosen people, some pair of them will have the same <a href="/w/index.php?title=Birthday&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Birthday (page does not exist)">birthday</a>. By the <a href="/wiki/Pigeonhole_principle" title="Pigeonhole principle">pigeonhole principle</a>, the probability reaches 100% when the number of people reaches 367 (since there are 366 possible birthdays, including February 29). However, 99.9% probability is reached with just 70 people, and 50% probability with 23 people. These conclusions include the assumption that each day of the year (except February 29) is equally probable for a birthday. The history of the problem is obscure, but <a href="/wiki/W._W._Rouse_Ball" title="W. W. Rouse Ball">W. W. Rouse Ball</a> indicated (without citation) that it was first discussed by an "H. Davenport", possibly <a href="/wiki/Harold_Davenport" title="Harold Davenport">Harold Davenport</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-rouse_ball_1960_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rouse_ball_1960-2">[2]</a></sup>
</p><p>The mathematics behind this problem led to a well-known cryptographic attack called the <a href="/wiki/Birthday_attack" title="Birthday attack">birthday attack</a>, which uses this probabilistic model to reduce the complexity of cracking a <a href="/wiki/Hash_function" title="Hash function">hash function</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Birthday_Paradox.svg" title="File:Birthday Paradox.svg">File:Birthday Paradox.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A graph showing the computed probability of at least two people sharing a birthday amongst a certain number of people.</div></div></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Understanding_the_problem">Understanding the problem</span></h2>
<p>The Birthday Problem is to find the probability that, in a group of N people, there is at least one pair of people who have the same birthday. See "<a href="#Same_birthday_as_you">Same birthday as you</a>" below for an analysis of the case of finding the probability of a given, fixed person having the same birthday as any of the remaining N - 1.
</p><p>In the example given earlier, a list of 23 people, comparing the birthday of the first person on the list to the others allows 22 chances for a matching birthday, the second person on the list to the others allows 21 chances for a matching birthday, third person has 20 chances, and so on. Hence total chances are: 22+21+20+....+1 = 253, so comparing every person to all of the others allows 253 distinct chances (<a href="/wiki/Combination" title="Combination">combinations</a>): in a group of 23 people there are &lt;math&gt;\textstyle {23 \choose 2} = \frac{23 \cdot 22}{2} = 253&lt;/math&gt; pairs.
</p><p>Presuming all birthdays are equally probable,<sup id="cite_ref-nonuniform_birthdays_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nonuniform_birthdays-3">[3]</a></sup> the probability of a given birthday for a person chosen from the entire population at random is 1/365 (ignoring <a href="/wiki/February_29" title="February 29">Leap Day</a>, February 29).  Although the pairings in a group of 23 people are not statistically equivalent to 253 pairs chosen independently, the birthday paradox becomes less surprising if a group is thought of in terms of the number of possible pairs, rather than as the number of individuals.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Calculating_the_probability">Calculating the probability</span></h2>
<p>The problem is to compute the approximate probability that in a room of <i>n</i> people, at least two have the same birthday. For simplicity, disregard variations in the distribution, such as <a href="/wiki/Leap_year" title="Leap year">leap years</a>, <a href="/wiki/Twin" title="Twin">twins</a>, seasonal or weekday variations, and assume that the 365 possible birthdays are equally likely. Real-life birthday distributions are not uniform since not all dates are equally likely.<sup id="cite_ref-nonuniform_birthdays_3-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nonuniform_birthdays-3">[3]</a></sup>
</p><p>If <i>P</i>(<i>A</i>) is the probability of at least two people in the room having the same birthday, it may be simpler to calculate <i>P</i>(<i>A</i>'), the probability of there not being any two people having the same birthday. Then, because <i>A</i> and <i>A</i>' are the only two possibilities and are also <a href="/wiki/Mutually_exclusive_events" title="Mutually exclusive events">mutually exclusive</a>, <i>P</i>(<i>A</i>)&#160;=&#160;1&#160;−&#160;<i>P</i>(<i>A</i>').
</p><p>In deference to widely published solutions concluding that 23 is the number of people necessary to have a <i>P</i>(<i>A</i>) that is greater than 50%, the following calculation of <i>P</i>(<i>A</i>) will use 23 people as an example.
</p><p>When events are <a href="/wiki/Independence_(probability_theory)" title="Independence (probability theory)">independent</a> of each other, the probability of all of the events occurring is equal to a product of the probabilities of each of the events occurring.  Therefore, if <i>P</i>(<i>A</i>') can be described as 23 independent events, <i>P</i>(<i>A</i>') could be calculated as <i>P</i>(1)&#160;×&#160;P(2)&#160;×&#160;P(3)&#160;×&#160;...&#160;×&#160;<i>P</i>(23).
</p><p>The 23 independent events correspond to the 23 people, and can be defined in order.  Each event can be defined as the corresponding person not sharing his/her birthday with any of the previously analyzed people.  For Event 1, there are no previously analyzed people.  Therefore, the probability, <i>P</i>(1), that person number 1 does not share his/her birthday with previously analyzed people is 1, or 100%.  Ignoring leap years for this analysis, the probability of 1 can also be written as 365/365, for reasons that will become clear below.
</p><p>For Event 2, the only previously analyzed people is Person 1.  Assuming that birthdays are equally likely to happen on each of the 365 days of the year, the probability, <i>P</i>(2), that Person 2 has a different birthday than Person 1 is 364/365.  This is because, if Person 2 was born on any of the other 364 days of the year, Persons 1 and 2 will not share the same birthday.
</p><p>Similarly, if Person 3 is born on any of the 363 days of the year other than the birthdays of Persons 1 and 2, Person 3 will not share their birthday.  This makes the probability <i>P</i>(3)&#160;=&#160;363/365.
</p><p>This analysis continues until Person 23 is reached, whose probability of not sharing his/her birthday with people analyzed before, <i>P</i>(23), is 343/365.
</p><p><i>P</i>(<i>A</i>') is equal to the product of these individual probabilities:
</p>
<dl>
<dd> (1) <i>P</i>(<i>A</i>') = 365/365&#160;×&#160;364/365&#160;×&#160;363/365&#160;×&#160;362/365&#160;×&#160;...&#160;×&#160;343/365
</dd>
</dl>
<p>The terms of equation (1) can be collected to arrive at:
</p>
<dl>
<dd> (2) <i>P</i>(<i>A</i>') = (1/365)<sup>23</sup>&#160;×&#160;(365&#160;×&#160;364&#160;×&#160;363&#160;×&#160;...&#160;×&#160;343)
</dd>
</dl>
<p>Evaluating equation (2) gives <i>P</i>(<i>A</i>') ≈&#160;0.492703
</p><p>Therefore, <i>P</i>(<i>A</i>) ≈&#160;1&#160;−&#160;0.492703 =&#160;0.507297&#160;(50.7297%)
</p><p>This process can be generalized to a group of <i>n</i> people, where <i>p</i>(<i>n</i>) is the probability of at least two of the <i>n</i> people sharing a birthday.  It is easier to first calculate the probability <i><u style="text-decoration:overline">p</u></i>(<i>n</i>) that all <i>n</i> birthdays are <i>different</i>.  According to the <a href="/wiki/Pigeonhole_principle" title="Pigeonhole principle">pigeonhole principle</a>, <i><u style="text-decoration:overline">p</u></i>(<i>n</i>) is zero when&#160;<i>n</i>&#160;&gt;&#160;365.  When&#160;<i>n</i>&#160;≤&#160;365:
</p>
<dl>
<dd>&lt;math&gt; \begin{align} \bar p(n) &amp;= 1 \times \left(1-\frac{1}{365}\right) \times \left(1-\frac{2}{365}\right) \times \cdots \times \left(1-\frac{n-1}{365}\right) \\  &amp;= { 365 \times 364 \times \cdots \times (365-n+1) \over 365^n } \\ &amp;= { 365! \over 365^n (365-n)!} = \frac{n!\cdot{365 \choose n}}{365^n} = \frac{_{365}P_n}{365^n}\end{align} &lt;/math&gt;
</dd>
</dl>
<p>where '&#160;! ' is the <a href="/wiki/Factorial" title="Factorial">factorial</a> operator, &lt;math&gt;\textstyle {365 \choose n}&lt;/math&gt; is the <a href="/wiki/Binomial_coefficient" title="Binomial coefficient">binomial coefficient</a> and &lt;math&gt;{_{k}P_r}&lt;/math&gt; denotes <a href="/wiki/Permutation" title="Permutation">permutation</a>.
</p><p>The equation expresses the fact that the first person has no one to share a birthday, the second person cannot have the same birthday as the first (364/365), the third cannot have the same birthday as the first two (363/365), and in general the <i>n</i><sup>th</sup> birthday cannot be the same as any of the <i>n</i>&#160;−&#160;1 preceding birthdays.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Event_(probability_theory)" title="Event (probability theory)">event</a> of at least two of the <i>n</i> persons having the same birthday is <a href="/wiki/Complementary_event" title="Complementary event">complementary</a> to all <i>n</i> birthdays being different. Therefore, its probability <i>p</i>(<i>n</i>) is
</p>
<dl>
<dd>&lt;math&gt; p(n) = 1 - \bar p(n). \, &lt;/math&gt;
</dd>
</dl>
<p>This probability surpasses 1/2 for&#160;<i>n</i>&#160;=&#160;23 (with value about&#160;50.7%). The following table shows the probability for some other values of <i>n</i> (this table ignores the existence of leap years, as described above):
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Birthdaymatch.svg" title="File:Birthdaymatch.svg">File:Birthdaymatch.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The probability that no two people share a birthday in a group of <i>n</i> people. Note that the vertical scale is logarithmic (each step down is 10<sup>20</sup> times less likely).</div></div></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Abstract_proof">Abstract proof</span></h2>
<p>Here we prove the same result as above, but with results about sets and functions to provide a simpler proof.
</p><p>Firstly, define &lt;math&gt;\mathcal{S} &lt;/math&gt; to be a set of N people and let &lt;math&gt;\mathcal{B} &lt;/math&gt; be the set of dates in a year.
</p><p>Define the birthday function &lt;math&gt; b:\mathcal{S} \mapsto \mathcal{B} &lt;/math&gt; to be the map that sends a person to their birthdate. Then it is obvious that everyone in &lt;math&gt;\mathcal{S}&lt;/math&gt; has a unique birthday if and only if the birthday function is <a href="/wiki/Injective" title="Injective" class="mw-redirect">injective</a>.
</p><p>Now we consider how many functions, and how many injective functions, exist between &lt;math&gt;\mathcal{S}&lt;/math&gt; and &lt;math&gt;\mathcal{B}&lt;/math&gt;.
</p><p>Since &lt;math&gt;|\mathcal{S}| = N&lt;/math&gt; and &lt;math&gt;|\mathcal{B}|=365&lt;/math&gt;, it follows that there are &lt;math&gt;365^N&lt;/math&gt; possible functions,<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">[4]</a></sup> and &lt;math&gt;\dfrac{365!}{(365-N)!} &lt;/math&gt; possible injective functions (see <a href="/w/index.php?title=Twelvefold_way&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Twelvefold way (page does not exist)">Twelvefold way#case i</a>).
</p><p>Let A be the statement "Everybody in the set &lt;math&gt;\mathcal{S}&lt;/math&gt; has a unique birthday" (so P(A') is what we are actually looking for). By definition, P(A) is the fraction of injective functions out of all possible functions (i.e., the probability of the birthday function being one that assigns only one person to each birthdate), which gives &lt;math&gt;P(A) = \dfrac{365!}{365^N(365-N)!}&lt;/math&gt;.
</p><p>Hence, &lt;math&gt;P(A') = 1 -\dfrac{365!}{365^N(365-N)!}&lt;/math&gt;
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Approximations">Approximations</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Birthday_paradox_probability.svg" title="File:Birthday paradox probability.svg">File:Birthday paradox probability.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Graphs showing the approximate probabilities of at least two people sharing a birthday (red) and its complementary event (blue)</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:050329-birthday2.png" title="File:050329-birthday2.png">File:050329-birthday2.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A graph showing the accuracy of the approximation &lt;math&gt;1-e^{-n^2/(2 \times 365)}&lt;/math&gt; (white)</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Taylor_series" title="Taylor series">Taylor series</a> expansion of the <a href="/wiki/Exponential_function" title="Exponential function">exponential function</a> (the constant e ≈ 2.718281828)
</p>
<dl>
<dd>&lt;math&gt; e^x = 1 + x + \frac{x^2}{2!}+\cdots &lt;/math&gt;
</dd>
</dl>
<p>provides a first-order approximation for <i>e</i><sup><i>x</i></sup> for <i>x</i> ≪ 1:
</p>
<dl>
<dd>&lt;math&gt; e^x \approx 1 + x.\ &lt;/math&gt;
</dd>
</dl>
<p>To apply this approximation to the first expression derived for <i><u style="text-decoration:overline">p</u></i>(<i>n</i>), set &lt;math&gt; x = -i / 365\ &lt;/math&gt;. Thus,
</p>
<dl>
<dd>&lt;math&gt; e^{-i/365} \approx 1 - \frac{i}{365}. \ &lt;/math&gt;
</dd>
</dl>
<p>Then, replace <i>i</i> with non-negative integers for each term in the formula of <i><u style="text-decoration:overline">p</u></i>(<i>n</i>) until <i>i</i> = <i>n</i> − 1, for example, when <i>i</i> = 1,
</p>
<dl>
<dd>&lt;math&gt; e^{-1/365} \approx 1 - \frac{1}{365}. \ &lt;/math&gt;
</dd>
</dl>
<p>The first expression derived for <i><u style="text-decoration:overline">p</u></i>(<i>n</i>) can be approximated as
</p>
<dl>
<dd>&lt;math&gt;
</dd>
</dl>
<p>\begin{align}
\bar p(n) &amp; \approx 1 \times e^{-1/365} \times e^{-2/365} \cdots e^{-(n-1)/365} \\
&amp; = 1 \times e^{-(1+2+ \cdots +(n-1))/365} \\
&amp; = e^{-(n(n-1)/2) / 365}.
\end{align}
&lt;/math&gt;
</p><p>Therefore,
</p>
<dl>
<dd>&lt;math&gt; p(n) = 1-\bar p(n) \approx 1 - e^{- n(n-1)/(2 \times 365)}.&lt;/math&gt;
</dd>
</dl>
<p>An even coarser approximation is given by
</p>
<dl>
<dd>&lt;math&gt;p(n)\approx 1-e^{- n^2/(2 \times 365)},\,&lt;/math&gt;
</dd>
</dl>
<p>which, as the graph illustrates, is still fairly accurate.
</p><p>According to the approximation, the same approach can be applied to any number of "people" and "days". If rather than 365 days there are <i>n</i>, if there are <i>m</i> persons, and if <i>m</i> ≪ <i>n</i>, then using the same approach as above we achieve the result that if <i>Pr</i>[(<i>m</i>, <i>n</i>)] is the probability that at least two out of <i>m</i> people share the same birthday from a set of <i>n</i> available days, then:
</p>
<dl>
<dd>&lt;math&gt; Pr[(m, n)] \approx 1-e^{-m^2 / 2n}.\ &lt;/math&gt;
</dd>
</dl>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="A_simple_exponentiation">A simple exponentiation</span></h3>
<p>The probability of any two people not having the same birthday is 364/365. In a room containing <i>n</i> people, there are <i>C</i>(<i>n</i>,&#160;2)&#160;=&#160;<i>n</i>(<i>n</i>&#160;−&#160;1)/2 pairs of people, i.e. <i>C</i>(<i>n</i>,&#160;2) events.  The probability of no two people sharing the same birthday can be approximated by assuming that these events are independent and hence by multiplying their probability together. In short 364/365 can be multiplied by itself <i>C</i>(<i>n</i>,&#160;2) times, which gives us
</p>
<dl>
<dd>&lt;math&gt;\bar p(n) \approx \left(\frac{364}{365}\right)^{C(n,2)}.&lt;/math&gt;
</dd>
</dl>
<p>Since this is the probability of no one having the same birthday, then the probability of someone sharing a birthday is
</p>
<dl>
<dd>&lt;math&gt;p(n) \approx 1 - \left(\frac{364}{365}\right)^{C(n,2)}.&lt;/math&gt;
</dd>
</dl>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Poisson_approximation">Poisson approximation</span></h3>
<p>Applying the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Poisson_distribution&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Poisson distribution (page does not exist)">Poisson</a> approximation for the binomial on the group of 23 people,
</p>
<dl>
<dd>&lt;math&gt;\mathrm{Poi}\left(\frac{C(23, 2)}{365}\right) =\mathrm{Poi}\left(\frac{253}{365}\right) \approx \mathrm{Poi}(0.6932)&lt;/math&gt;
</dd>
</dl>
<dl>
<dd>&lt;math&gt;\Pr(X&gt;0)=1-\Pr(X=0) \approx 1-e^{-0.6932} \approx 1-0.499998=0.500002.&lt;/math&gt;
</dd>
</dl>
<p>The result is over 50% as previous descriptions.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Square_approximation">Square approximation</span></h3>
<p>A good <a href="/wiki/Rule_of_thumb" title="Rule of thumb">rule of thumb</a> which can be used for <a href="/wiki/Mental_calculation" title="Mental calculation">mental calculation</a> is the relation
</p>
<dl>
<dd>&lt;math&gt;p(n) \approx {n^2 \over 2m}&lt;/math&gt;
</dd>
</dl>
<p>which can also be written as
</p>
<dl>
<dd>&lt;math&gt;n \approx \sqrt { 2m \times p(n)}&lt;/math&gt;
</dd>
</dl>
<p>which works well for probabilities less than or equal to 0.5.
</p><p>For instance, to estimate the number of people required for a 0.5 chance of a shared birthday, we get
</p>
<dl>
<dd>&lt;math&gt;n \approx \sqrt{ 2 \times 365 \times 0.5} = \sqrt{365} \approx 19&lt;/math&gt;
</dd>
</dl>
<p>Which is not too far from the correct answer of 23.
</p><p>This approximation scheme is especially easy to use for when working with exponents. For instance, suppose you are building 32 bit hashes (&lt;math&gt; m = 2^{32}&lt;/math&gt;) and want the chance of a collision to be at most one in a million (&lt;math&gt; p \approx 2^{-20} &lt;/math&gt;), how many documents could we have at the most?
</p>
<dl>
<dd>&lt;math&gt;n \approx \sqrt { 2 \times 2^{32} \times 2^{-20}} = \sqrt { 2^{1+32-20} } = \sqrt { 2^{13} } = 2^{6.5} \approx 90.5 &lt;/math&gt;
</dd>
</dl>
<p>which is close to the correct answer of 93.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Approximation_of_number_of_people">Approximation of number of people</span></h3>
<p>This can also be approximated using the following formula for the <i>number</i> of people necessary to have at least a 50% chance of matching:
</p>
<dl>
<dd>&lt;math&gt;n \approx \frac{1}{2} + \sqrt{\frac{1}{4} - 2 \times 365 \times \ln(0.5)} = 22.999943.&lt;/math&gt;
</dd>
</dl>
<p>This is a result of the good approximation that an event with 1 in <i>k</i> probability will have a 50% chance of occurring at least once if it is repeated <i>k</i>&#160;ln&#160;2 times.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5]</a></sup>
</p>

<p>The white fields in this table show the number of hashes needed to achieve the given probability of collision (column) given a hash space of a certain size in bits (row). Using the birthday analogy: the "hash space size" resembles the "available days", the "probability of collision" resembles the "probability of shared birthday", and the "required number of hashed elements" resembles the "required number of people in a group". One could of course also use this chart to determine the minimum hash size required (given upper bounds on the hashes and probability of error), or the probability of collision (for fixed number of hashes and probability of error).
</p><p>For comparison, 10<sup>−18</sup> to 10<sup>−15</sup> is the uncorrectable bit error rate of a typical hard disk.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">[6]</a></sup> In theory, 128-bit hash functions, such as <a href="/wiki/MD5" title="MD5">MD5</a>, should stay within that range until about 820 billion documents, even if its possible outputs are many more.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="An_upper_bound">An upper bound</span></h2>
<p>The argument below is adapted from an argument of <a href="/wiki/Paul_Halmos" title="Paul Halmos">Paul Halmos</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup>
</p><p>As stated above, the probability that no two birthdays coincide is
</p>
<dl>
<dd>&lt;math&gt;1-p(n) = \bar p(n) = \prod_{k=1}^{n-1}\left(1-{k \over 365}\right) .&lt;/math&gt;
</dd>
</dl>
<p>As in earlier paragraphs, interest lies in the smallest <i>n</i> such that <i>p</i>(<i>n</i>)&#160;&gt;&#160;1/2; or equivalently, the smallest <i>n</i> such that <i><u style="text-decoration:overline">p</u></i>(<i>n</i>)&#160;&lt;&#160;1/2.
</p><p>Using the inequality 1&#160;−&#160;<i>x</i>&#160;&lt;&#160;<i>e</i><sup>−<i>x</i></sup> in the above expression we replace 1&#160;−&#160;<i>k</i>/365 with <i>e</i><sup>−<i>k</i>/365</sup>. This yields
</p>
<dl>
<dd>&lt;math&gt;\bar p(n) = \prod_{k=1}^{n-1}\left(1-{k \over 365}\right) &lt; \prod_{k=1}^{n-1}\left(e^{-k/365}\right) = e^{-(n(n-1))/(2\times 365)} .&lt;/math&gt;
</dd>
</dl>
<p>Therefore, the expression above is not only an approximation, but also an <a href="/w/index.php?title=Upper_bound&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Upper bound (page does not exist)">upper bound</a> of <i><u style="text-decoration:overline">p</u></i>(<i>n</i>). The inequality
</p>
<dl>
<dd>&lt;math&gt; e^{-(n(n-1))/(2\cdot 365)} &lt; \frac{1}{2}&lt;/math&gt;
</dd>
</dl>
<p>implies <i><u style="text-decoration:overline">p</u></i>(<i>n</i>)&#160;&lt;&#160;1/2. Solving for <i>n</i> gives
</p>
<dl>
<dd>&lt;math&gt;n^2-n &gt; 2\times365\ln 2 \,\! .&lt;/math&gt;
</dd>
</dl>
<p>Now, 730&#160;ln&#160;2 is approximately 505.997, which is barely below 506, the value of <i>n</i><sup>2</sup>&#160;−&#160;<i>n</i> attained when <i>n</i>&#160;=&#160;23. Therefore, 23 people suffice.
Solving <i>n</i><sup>2</sup>&#160;−&#160;<i>n</i> =&#160;2&#160;·&#160;365&#160;·&#160;ln&#160;2 for <i>n</i> gives, by the way, the approximate formula of Frank H. Mathis cited above.
</p><p>This derivation only shows that <i>at most</i> 23 people are needed to ensure a birthday match with even chance; it leaves open the possibility that <i>n</i> is 22 or less could also work.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Generalizations">Generalizations</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="The_generalized_birthday_problem">The generalized birthday problem</span></h3>
<p>Given a year with <i>d</i> days, the <b>generalized birthday problem</b> asks for the minimal number <i>n</i>(<i>d</i>) such that, in a set of <i>n</i>(<i>d</i>) randomly chosen people, the probability of a birthday coincidence is at least 50%.
In other words, <i>n</i>(<i>d</i>) is the minimal integer <i>n</i> such that
</p>
<dl>
<dd>&lt;math&gt;1-\left(1-\frac{1}{d}\right)\left(1-\frac{2}{d}\right)\cdots\left(1-\frac{n-1}{d}\right)\geq \frac{1}{2}.&lt;/math&gt;
</dd>
</dl>
<p>The classical birthday problem thus corresponds to determining <i>n</i>(365). The first 99 values of <i>n</i>(<i>d</i>) are given here:
</p>
<dl><dd><table class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;">

<tr>
<th scope="row"> <i>d</i>
</th>
<td> 1–2 </td>
<td> 3–5 </td>
<td> 6–9 </td>
<td> 10–16 </td>
<td> 17–23 </td>
<td> 24–32 </td>
<td> 33–42 </td>
<td> 43–54 </td>
<td> 55–68 </td>
<td> 69–82 </td>
<td> 83–99
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th scope="row"> <i>n</i>(<i>d</i>)
</th>
<td> 2 </td>
<td> 3 </td>
<td> 4 </td>
<td> 5 </td>
<td> 6 </td>
<td> 7 </td>
<td> 8 </td>
<td> 9 </td>
<td> 10 </td>
<td> 11 </td>
<td> 12
</td></tr></table></dd></dl>
<p>A number of bounds and formulas for <i>n</i>(<i>d</i>) have been published.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup>
For any <i>d</i>≥1, the number <i>n</i>(<i>d</i>) satisfies<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">[9]</a></sup>
</p>
<dl>
<dd>&lt;math&gt;\frac{3-2\ln2}{6}&lt;n(d)-\sqrt{2d\ln2}\leq 9-\sqrt{86\ln2}.&lt;/math&gt;
</dd>
</dl>
<p>These bounds are optimal in the sense that the sequence &lt;math&gt;n(d)-\sqrt{2d\ln2}&lt;/math&gt;
gets arbitrarily close to &lt;math&gt;(3-2\ln2)/6\approx 0.27&lt;/math&gt;, while it has &lt;math&gt;9-\sqrt{86\ln2}\approx 1.28&lt;/math&gt; as its maximum, taken for <i>d</i>=43.
The bounds are sufficiently tight to give the exact value of <i>n</i>(<i>d</i>) in 99% of all cases, for example <i>n</i>(365)=23.
In general, it follows from these bounds that <i>n</i>(<i>d</i>) always equals either
&lt;math&gt;\left\lceil\sqrt{2d\ln2}\right\rceil&lt;/math&gt; or &lt;math&gt;\left\lceil\sqrt{2d\ln2}\right\rceil+1&lt;/math&gt; where &lt;math&gt;\lceil x \rceil&lt;/math&gt; denotes the <a href="/wiki/Floor_and_ceiling_functions" title="Floor and ceiling functions">ceiling function</a>.
The formula
</p>
<dl>
<dd>&lt;math&gt;n(d) = \left\lceil\sqrt{2d\ln2}\right\rceil&lt;/math&gt;
</dd>
</dl>
<p>holds for 73% of all integers <i>d</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-Brink_10-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Brink-10">[10]</a></sup>
The formula
</p>
<dl>
<dd>&lt;math&gt;n(d) = \left\lceil\sqrt{2d\ln2}+\frac{3-2\ln2}{6}\right\rceil&lt;/math&gt;
</dd>
</dl>
<p>holds for <a href="/wiki/Almost_all" title="Almost all">almost all</a> <i>d</i>, i.e., for a set of integers <i>d</i> with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Asymptotic_density&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Asymptotic density (page does not exist)">asymptotic density</a> 1.<sup id="cite_ref-Brink_10-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Brink-10">[10]</a></sup> The formula
</p>
<dl>
<dd>&lt;math&gt;n(d)=\left\lceil \sqrt{2d\ln2}+\frac{3-2\ln2}{6}+\frac{9-4(\ln2)^2}{72\sqrt{2d\ln2}}
</dd>
</dl>
<p>\right\rceil&lt;/math&gt;
</p><p>holds for all <i>d</i> up to 10<sup>18</sup>, but it is conjectured that there are infinitely many counter-examples to this formula.<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_11-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-11">[11]</a></sup>
The formula
</p>
<dl>
<dd>&lt;math&gt;n(d)=\left\lceil \sqrt{2d\ln2}+\frac{3-2\ln2}{6}+\frac{9-4(\ln2)^2}{72\sqrt{2d\ln2}}
</dd>
</dl>
<p>-\frac{2(\ln2)^2}{135d}\right\rceil&lt;/math&gt;
</p><p>holds too for all <i>d</i> up to 10<sup>18</sup>, and it is conjectured that this formula holds for all <i>d</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_11-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-11">[11]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cast_as_a_collision_problem">Cast as a collision problem</span></h3>
<p>The birthday problem can be generalized as follows{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}: given <i>n</i> random integers drawn from a <a href="/wiki/Uniform_distribution_(discrete)" title="Uniform distribution (discrete)">discrete uniform distribution</a> with range [1,<i>d</i>], what is the probability <i>p</i>(<i>n</i>;<i>d</i>) that at least two numbers are the same? (<i>d=365</i> gives the usual birthday problem.)
</p><p>The generic results can be derived using the same arguments given above.
</p>
<dl>
<dd>&lt;math&gt;p(n;d) = \begin{cases} 1-\prod_{k=1}^{n-1}\left(1-{k \over d}\right) &amp; n\le d \\ 1 &amp; n &gt; d \end{cases}&lt;/math&gt;
</dd>
<dd>&lt;math&gt;p(n;d) \approx 1 - e^{-n(n-1)/(2d)}&lt;/math&gt;
</dd>
<dd>&lt;math&gt;p(n;d) \approx 1 - \left( \frac{d-1}{d} \right)^{n(n-1)/2}&lt;/math&gt;
</dd>
</dl>
<p>Conversely, if <i>n(p;d)</i> denotes the number of random integers drawn from [1,<i>d</i>] to obtain a probability <i>p</i> that at least two numbers are the same, then
</p>
<dl>
<dd>&lt;math&gt;n(p;d)\approx \sqrt{2d \cdot \ln\left({1 \over 1-p}\right)}.&lt;/math&gt;
</dd>
</dl>
<p>The birthday problem in this more generic sense applies to <a href="/wiki/Hash_function" title="Hash function">hash functions</a>: the expected number of <i>N</i>-<a href="/wiki/Bit" title="Bit">bit</a> hashes that can be generated before getting a collision is not 2<sup><i>N</i></sup>, but rather only 2<sup><i>N</i>/2</sup>. This is exploited by <a href="/wiki/Birthday_attack" title="Birthday attack">birthday attacks</a> on <a href="/wiki/Cryptographic_hash_function" title="Cryptographic hash function">cryptographic hash functions</a> and is the reason why a small number of collisions in a <a href="/wiki/Hash_table" title="Hash table">hash table</a> are, for all practical purposes, inevitable.
</p><p>The theory behind the birthday problem was used by Zoe Schnabel<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup> under the name of <a href="/wiki/Mark_and_recapture" title="Mark and recapture">capture-recapture</a> statistics to estimate the size of fish population in lakes.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Generalization_to_multiple_types">Generalization to multiple types</span></h4>
<p>The basic problem considers all trials to be of one "type". The  birthday problem has been generalized to consider an arbitrary number of types.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup> In the simplest extension there are two types of people, say <i>m</i> men and <i>n</i> women, and the problem becomes characterizing the probability of a shared birthday between at least one man and one woman. (Shared birthdays between, say, two women do not count.) The probability of <i>no</i> (i.e. zero) shared birthdays here is
</p>
<dl>
<dd>&lt;math&gt;p_0 =1 - \frac{1}{d^{m+n}} \sum_{i=1}^m \sum_{j=1}^n S_2(m,i) S_2(n,j) \prod_{k=0}^{i+j-1} d - k&lt;/math&gt;
</dd>
</dl>
<p>where <i>d</i>&#160;=&#160;365 and <i>S</i><sub>2</sub> are <a href="/wiki/Stirling_number" title="Stirling number">Stirling numbers of the second kind</a>. Consequently, the desired probability is 1&#160;−&#160;<i>p</i><sub>0</sub>.
</p><p>This variation of the birthday problem is interesting because there is not a unique solution for the total number of people <i>m</i>&#160;+&#160;<i>n</i>. For example, the usual 0.5 probability value is realized for both a 32-member group of 16 men and 16 women and a 49-member group of 43 women and 6 men.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Other_birthday_problems">Other birthday problems</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Reverse_problem">Reverse problem</span></h3>
<p>For a fixed probability <i>p</i>:
</p>
<ul>
<li> Find the greatest <i>n</i> for which the probability <i>p</i>(<i>n</i>) is smaller than the given <i>p</i>, or
</li>
<li> Find the smallest <i>n</i> for which the probability <i>p</i>(<i>n</i>) is greater than the given <i>p</i>.
</li>
</ul>
<p>Taking the above formula for <i>d</i>&#160;=&#160;365 we have:
</p>
<dl>
<dd>&lt;math&gt;n(p;365)\approx \sqrt{2\times 365\ln\left({1 \over 1-p}\right)}.&lt;/math&gt;
</dd>
</dl>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="First_match">First match</span></h3>
<p>A related question is, as people enter a room one at a time, which one is most likely to be the first to have the same birthday as someone already in the room?  That is, for what <i>n</i> is <i>p</i>(<i>n</i>)&#160;−&#160;<i>p</i>(<i>n</i>&#160;−&#160;1) maximum?  The answer is 20—if there's a prize for first match, the best position in line is 20th.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Same_birthday_as_you">Same birthday as you</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Birthday_paradox.svg" title="File:Birthday paradox.svg">File:Birthday paradox.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Comparing <i>p</i>(<i>n</i>) = probability of a birthday match with <i>q</i>(<i>n</i>) = probability of matching <i>your</i> birthday</div></div></div>
<p>Note that in the birthday problem, neither of the two people is chosen in advance. By way of contrast, the probability <i>q</i>(<i>n</i>) that someone in a room of <i>n</i> other people has the same birthday  as a particular person (for example, you), is given by
</p>
<dl>
<dd> &lt;math&gt; q(n) = 1 - \left( \frac{365-1}{365} \right)^n &lt;/math&gt;
</dd>
</dl>
<p>and for general <i>d</i> by
</p>
<dl>
<dd> &lt;math&gt; q(n;d) = 1 - \left( \frac{d-1}{d} \right)^n. &lt;/math&gt;
</dd>
</dl>
<p>In the standard case of <i>d</i> = 365 substituting <i>n</i> = 23 gives about 6.1%, which is less than 1 chance in 16.  For a greater than 50% chance that one person in a roomful of <i>n</i> people has the same birthday as <i>you</i>, <i>n</i> would need to be at least 253. Note that this number is significantly higher than 365/2 = 182.5: the reason is that it is likely that there are some birthday matches among the other people in the room.
</p><p>It is not a coincidence that &lt;math&gt;253=\frac{23\times(23-1)}{2}&lt;/math&gt;; a similar approximate pattern can be found using a number of possibilities different from 365, or a target probability different from 50%.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Near_matches">Near matches</span></h3>
<p>Another generalization is to ask what is the probability of finding at least one pair in a group of <i>n</i> people with birthdays within <i>k</i> calendar days of each other's, if there are <i>m</i> equally likely birthdays.
</p>
<dl>
<dd>&lt;math&gt; \begin{align} p(n,k,m) &amp;= 1 - { (m - nk -1)! \over m^{n-1} (m - n(k+1))!}\end{align} &lt;/math&gt;<sup id="cite_ref-abramson_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-abramson-14">[14]</a></sup>
</dd>
</dl>
<p>The number of people required so that the probability that some pair will have a birthday separated by  <i>k</i> days or fewer will be higher than 50% is:
</p>
<table class="wikitable" style="text-align: center">
<tr>
<th> <i>k</i> </th>
<th> # people required(i.e. <i>n</i>) when <i>m</i>=365
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td>0 </td>
<td> 23
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>1 </td>
<td> 14
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>2 </td>
<td> 11
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>3 </td>
<td> 9
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>4 </td>
<td> 8
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>5 </td>
<td> 8
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>6 </td>
<td> 7
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>7 </td>
<td> 7
</td></tr></table>
<p>Thus in a group of just seven random people, it is more likely than not that two of them will have a birthday within a week of each other.<sup id="cite_ref-abramson_14-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-abramson-14">[14]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Collision_counting">Collision counting</span></h3>
<p>The probability that the <i>k</i>th integer randomly chosen from [1,&#160;<i>d</i>] will repeat at least one previous choice equals <i>q</i>(<i>k</i>&#160;−&#160;1;&#160;<i>d</i>) above.  The expected total number of times a selection will repeat a previous selection as <i>n</i> such integers are chosen equals{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}
</p>
<dl>
<dd>&lt;math&gt;\sum_{k=1}^n q(k-1;d) = n - d + d \left (\frac {d-1} {d} \right )^n.&lt;/math&gt;
</dd>
</dl>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Average_number_of_people">Average number of people</span></h3>
<p>In an alternative formulation of the birthday problem, one asks the <i>average</i> number of people required to find a pair with the same birthday. The problem is relevant to several <a href="/wiki/Hash_function" title="Hash function">hashing algorithms</a> analyzed by <a href="/wiki/Donald_Knuth" title="Donald Knuth">Donald Knuth</a> in his book <i><a href="/wiki/The_Art_of_Computer_Programming" title="The Art of Computer Programming">The Art of Computer Programming</a></i>. It may be shown<sup id="cite_ref-knuth73_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-knuth73-15">[15]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-flajolet95_16-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-flajolet95-16">[16]</a></sup> that if one samples uniformly, with replacement, from a population of size <i>M</i>, the number of trials required for the first repeated sampling of <i>some</i> individual has <a href="/wiki/Expected_value" title="Expected value">expected value</a> &lt;math&gt;\overline{n}\,=\,1+Q(M)&lt;/math&gt;, where
</p>
<dl>
<dd> &lt;math&gt;Q(M)=\sum_{k=1}^{M} \frac{M!}{(M-k)! M^k}.&lt;/math&gt;
</dd>
</dl>
<p>The function
</p>
<dl>
<dd> &lt;math&gt;Q(M)= 1 + \frac{M-1}{M} + \frac{(M-1)(M-2)}{M^2} + \cdots + \frac{(M-1)(M-2) \cdots 1}{M^{M-1}}&lt;/math&gt;
</dd>
</dl>
<p>has been studied by <a href="/wiki/Srinivasa_Ramanujan" title="Srinivasa Ramanujan">Srinivasa Ramanujan</a> and has <a href="/wiki/Asymptotic_expansion" title="Asymptotic expansion">asymptotic expansion</a>:
</p>
<dl>
<dd> &lt;math&gt;Q(M)\sim\sqrt{\frac{\pi M}{2}}-\frac{1}{3}+\frac{1}{12}\sqrt{\frac{\pi}{2M}}-\frac{4}{135M}+\cdots.&lt;/math&gt;
</dd>
</dl>
<p>With <i>M</i>&#160;=&#160;365 days in a year, the average number of people required to find a pair with the same birthday is &lt;math&gt;\scriptstyle\overline{n}\,=\,1+Q(M)\approx 24.61658&lt;/math&gt;, slightly more than the number required for a 50% chance. In the best case, two people will suffice; at worst, the maximum possible number of <i>M</i>&#160;+&#160;1&#160;=&#160;366 people is needed; but on <a href="/wiki/Average" title="Average">average</a>, only 25 people are required.
</p><p>An <i>informal</i> demonstration of the problem can be made from the <a href="/wiki/List_of_Prime_Ministers_of_Australia" title="List of Prime Ministers of Australia">list of Prime Ministers of Australia</a>, of which there have been 27, in which <a href="/wiki/Paul_Keating" title="Paul Keating">Paul Keating</a>, the 24th Prime Minister, and <a href="/wiki/Edmund_Barton" title="Edmund Barton">Edmund Barton</a>, the first Prime Minister, share the same birthday, 18 January.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Partition_problem">Partition problem</span></h2>
<p>A related problem is the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Partition_problem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Partition problem (page does not exist)">partition problem</a>, a variant of the <a href="/wiki/Knapsack_problem" title="Knapsack problem">knapsack problem</a> from operations research. Some weights are put on a <a href="/wiki/Weighing_scale" title="Weighing scale">balance scale</a>; each weight is an integer number of grams randomly chosen between one gram and one million grams (one metric ton). The question is whether one can usually (that is, with probability close to 1) transfer the weights between the left and right arms to balance the scale. (In case the sum of all the weights is an odd number of grams, a discrepancy of one gram is allowed.) If there are only two or three weights, the answer is very clearly no; although there are some combinations which work, the majority of randomly selected combinations of three weights do not. If there are very many weights, the answer is clearly yes. The question is, how many are just sufficient? That is, what is the number of weights such that it is equally likely for it to be possible to balance them as it is to be impossible?
</p><p>Some people's intuition is that the answer is above 100,000. Most people's intuition is that it is in the thousands or tens of thousands, while others feel it should at least be in the hundreds. The correct answer is approximately 23.
</p><p>The reason is that the correct comparison is to the number of partitions of the weights into left and right. There are 2<sup><i>N</i>−1</sup> different partitions for <i>N</i> weights, and the left sum minus the right sum can be thought of as a new random quantity for each partition. The distribution of the sum of weights is approximately <a href="/wiki/Normal_distribution" title="Normal distribution">Gaussian</a>, with a peak at 1,000,000&#160;<i>N</i> and width &lt;math&gt;\scriptstyle 1,000,000\sqrt{N}&lt;/math&gt;, so that when 2<sup><i>N</i>−1</sup> is approximately equal to &lt;math&gt;\scriptstyle 1,000,000\sqrt{N}&lt;/math&gt; the transition occurs.  2<sup>23−1</sup> is about 4 million, while the width of the distribution is only 5 million.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="In_Fiction">In Fiction</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arthur_C._Clarke&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Arthur C. Clarke (page does not exist)">Arthur C. Clarke</a>'s novel <a href="/wiki/A_Fall_of_Moondust" title="A Fall of Moondust">A Fall of Moondust</a>, published in 1961, contains a section where the main characters, trapped underground for an indefinite amount of time, are celebrating a birthday and find themselves discussing the validity of the Birthday problem. As stated by a physicist passenger: "If you have a group of more than twenty-four people, the odds are better than even than two of them have the same birthday." Eventually, out of 22 present, it is revealed that two characters share the same birthday, i.e., May 23.
</p><p><br />
</p>
